reasoning:
The critique targets a key support for the paper’s “no easy eutopia” conclusion: the Section 2.3–2.4 idea that value is well-modeled as (roughly) a product of many quasi-independent factors such that one low dimension can wipe out most value. If this fragility/multiplicativity picture were substantially wrong, the intuitive case that ‘common-sense utopia’ is still far from mostly-great would weaken meaningfully—though the paper also has an independent, fairly central Section 3 argument from the structure of plausible value functions (bounded/unbounded, linearity, goods/bads aggregation), so refuting multiplicativity would not collapse the whole position.

Strength is moderate: the objection plausibly notes that independence is a strong assumption and that coupled systems can exhibit attractors and error-correction, which would make the toy percentile calculations inapplicable. However, it doesn’t show that the relevant moral-catastrophe dimensions are positively coupled in the right way (vs negatively coupled or correlated failure modes), nor that ‘common-sense utopia’ would robustly self-correct on the specific hard-to-notice issues the paper emphasizes (population ethics, digital minds’ status, space resource allocation), many of which could plausibly be locked in rather than locally repaired. It also doesn’t directly engage the paper’s broader ‘fussiness’ claims that don’t rely on independence.

Relevance is fairly high because it engages Forethought’s Tier-2 working assumption that eutopia is a narrow target and questions a recurring methodological move (multiplicative EV decompositions/product-of-factors), offering an alternative dynamical-systems framing (basins of attraction) that could change how they model flourishing-risk distributions, though it remains somewhat programmatic without concrete models or evidence.
title: "Tight coupling in advanced civilizations enables self-correcting flaws"
